text:
1. Your full name: GEORGE WALTER HILLIER

2. Your address (at present): PIONEER LODGE - ASSINIBOIA, SASK.

3. Date: MARCH 14, 1962

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): BRISTOL - ENGLAND

5. What was your father's name and occupation? CHARLES, HENRY - HILLIER, (Chinook)

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month, and year): APRIL 1904 - BORN DEC. 14, 1879

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: WINNIPEG, from April 1903 to May 1904

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.) TWELVE YEARS

9. What were your reasons for coming West? Not satisfied with conditions in England. Wanted to get away to something more promising. Had never worked on a farm, was always in the city. I was partly given to farming.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Railroad and Government advertising were very extensive at this time. Settlers were needed, and farmers were going through the Country advertising the possibilities of farming in Canada. It all sounded so wonderful to me! That I decided to come to Canada. When I arrived in Winnipeg in 1903, I had ten shillings in my pocket, if I had more I would have went right back again. I was homesick.
1. Your full name: GEORGE WALTER HILLIER
2. Your address (at present): PIONEER LODGE - ASSINIBOIA, SASK.
3. Date: MARCH 14, 1962
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): BRISTOL - ENGLAND
5. What was your father's name and occupation? CHARLES, HENRY HILLIER (Shoemaker)
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month, day, year): APRIL 1904 - Born Dec. 14, 1879
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: WINNIPEG, from April 1903 to May 1904
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.) Forty-three
9. What were your reasons for coming West? Not satisfied with conditions in Bristol. Wanted to get away to something more promising. Had never worked on a farm, was always in the city. I was partly given to farming.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) It all sounded so wonderful to me! That I decided to come to Canada. When I arrived in Winnipeg in 1903, I had ten shillings in my pocket, if I had more I would have gone right back again. I saw homesteads.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They thought it would be a bright.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   By myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   By steamship from Europe to Halifax, then by train to Winnipeg, (Emigrant train)

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   The train & story telling were coming to Canada.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   Macoun

16. From Macoun to Estevan - Field August 1909
   Moved onto land Spring 1910, located on the farm until Fall of 1948 then moved to village of Estevan, & work from & owning on account of sickness.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   (Laborer) worked at farming, until I was able to farm for myself.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They thought it would be alright.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
    By myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
    Train to Winnipeg. (Emigrant train)

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
    The Barn & story settler was coming to Canada.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
    Macoun

16. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
    Then Macoun to Estevan - Field August 1909

17. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How often did you come?
    (Unreadable) working at farming until I was able to farm for myself.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

About once a month.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married Jane Ann Burnett January 1918

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, as a place to settle?

One brother who served in the First World War, returned about 1950.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

Brother came out to Canada about 1890

Settled at Cross Lake District.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

It took to organize the first school district in this part of the country in 1910, when Sec. 3 was almost continuously until 1945, needed lumber for school from Ogema, about 100 miles north, and 200 miles south. We practically all community organized. We also applied for a lot of the Peace during the Anderson administration in the early 1930s.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Did not travel very much.

No stage and buggy, means of travel.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? It as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Did not travel very much.

Yes, we used a buggy, owned by friends.
25. When was the first car used in the community? About 1920.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make? No.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? Willow Bunch — 25 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.) Willow Bunch was an ideal town, half-truck haulers mechanized from Morse Jaw with horses. The railroads began coming into Ogema then Bergesford then Weyburn to reach in 1926 (now too late).

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? 1926 or 1927

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? Didn't make up my mind. If all no money so had to try and start work. I didn't go back to England for 58 years, went back '61 for 2 months. We are done family work during these years.
25. When was the first car used in the community? About 1920

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make? No.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? Willow Bunch — 25 miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.) The railroads began coming in 1926 (new two miles)

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? 1926-1927

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? (Include also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.)

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan, the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? Didn't make my mind. If all no money or hard to try land for 58 y didn't you tried to try land for 2 months. Yean, went back 1941 for 2 months. Please done family well among them years.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return in the 1930s?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If yes, of your family or friends were first to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

36. If you or some members of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. Mention if any of your family or friends were first to have or do something in the district (such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
6.

39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe.)

Would you or the person who owns them either
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

(Indicate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:
6.

39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe.)

Would you or the person who owns them either
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office of the University in Saskatoon?

(Indicate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:
Oxford

No. 613 S
